elementary OS is designed to run on any: elementary OS is designed to run on any relatively new 32-bit and 64-bit desktop or laptop. In this section, we'll cover system requirements and other prerequisites to installing elementary OS on your computer.
If you haven't already, you will need to: If you haven't already, you will need to download elementary OS from our home page. You will need to copy the downloaded ISO file to a USB flash drive using the instructions below.
elementary OS is currently built for two: elementary OS jelenleg két architektúrát támogat, 32 és 64-bitest.
If you know you have a newer computer wi: Ha egy újabb, 64bites processzorral szerelt számítógéppel rendelkezik, válassza a 64-bites változatot.
If your computer is older or you do not: Ha a számítógépe idősebb, vagy nem tudja milyen a gépe processzora, válassza a 32-bites változatot. (64-bites processzorok is képesek ezt a változatot futtatni.)
Make sure to back your important data up: Ellenőrizze, hogy készített-e biztonsági mentést külső tárhelyre, mint pl. felhőszolgáltatásra vagy külső merevlemezre. Egy operációs rendszer telepítése felülírhatja meglévő adatainkat.
Begin with a spare USB flash drive with: Kezdésnek szüksége lesz egy USB flash meghajtóra legalább 1GB szabad tárterülettel.
You'll also need a small application cal: Ezenfelül szükséges egy kis "Rufus" nevű program. Ez letölthető a weboldaláról, majd a letöltött fájlt nyissa meg. Egy ilyen ablak fogadja, mint ami lentebb látható:
You can now insert your USB drive and se: Helyezze be az USB-flash meghajtóját és válassza ki a "Device" listából. Ez után válassza az "ISO image" menüpontot a "Create a bootable disk using..." mellől, majd kattintson.
Click \"Start\", then just wait for the: Click "Start", then just wait for the process to finish.
You'll also need a small application cal: You'll also need a small application called UNetbootin. To install it in Ubuntu, just click this link. In OS X you'll have to download it from its website and open the downloaded file to install it.
Open UNetbootin from the Dash in Ubuntu: Open UNetbootin from the Dash in Ubuntu or Launchpad in OS X. It will open a window like the one below:
Make sure \"Diskimage\" is selected, and: Make sure "Diskimage" is selected, and click "…" to select the ISO that you downloaded previously. Unplug all USB memory devices apart from the one you want to use. Click "OK" and wait for the process to finish.
In order to start the installation proce: In order to start the installation process, you must boot your computer from the install drive. This process may differ depending on the type of computer you have. This guide covers the most common use cases.
Assuming that your computer is still on,: Assuming that your computer is still on, start by inserting your install drive and restarting your computer.
Most computers will briefly allow you to: Most computers will briefly allow you to change the boot order for this boot only by pressing a special key — usually <kbd>F12</kbd>, but sometimes <kbd>Esc</kbd> or another function key. Refer to the screen or your computer's documentation to be sure.
Press <kbd>F12</kbd> (or the appropriate: Press <kbd>F12</kbd> (or the appropriate key) and select the install drive—usually "USB-HDD" or something containing the word "USB", but the wording may vary. If you choose the incorrect drive, your computer will likely continue to boot as normal. Just restart your computer and pick a different drive in that menu.
Shortly after selecting the appropriate: Shortly after selecting the appropriate boot drive, you should be presented with the elementary OS splash screen. You may now follow the on-screen instructions which will guide you through the rest of the process.
After you hear the chime, press and hold: After you hear the chime, press and hold <kbd>Option</kbd>. Then, select the appropriate boot drive. Note that it may be incorrectly identified as "Windows", but this is normal.
